text:
Hi <@U01DEA6F7CH>! 

Ryan Pereus is one of my favorites (and not just bc he signs my checks :sweat_smile: lol) 
He is the founder and CEO of Superhuman Prospecting and the H2H Sales Method, which stands for Human-to-Human. 
We've been on a mission to change the way people think about B2B prospecting and cold calling in the 21st-century.

<https://youtube.com/c/SuperhumanProspecting|https://youtube.com/c/SuperhumanProspecting>

<https://www.linkedin.com/in/ryanpereus|https://www.linkedin.com/in/ryanpereus>

text:
i'm working on an article on content strategy and would love some input.
-
you're taking over content at a company. what are the various situations you walk into? examples:
• you're inheriting a mess
• you're starting from scratch
• you're taking over a great blog and want to make your own stamp

elements.text:
i'm working on an article on content strategy and would love some input.
-
you're taking over content at a company. what are the various situations you walk into? examples:
you're inheriting a mess
you're starting from scratch
you're taking over a great blog and want to make your own stamp

text:
"inheriting a mess" can be broken down into various messes :stuck_out_tongue:
• technical SEO mess, penalties
• lots of old outdated content
• blog is publishing low-quality content
• duplicate, disorganized content  - especially if it's unclear who does what - like blog content competing with docs which is run by a separate team

elements.text: "inheriting a mess" can be broken down into various messes
technical SEO mess, penalties
lots of old outdated content
blog is publishing low-quality content
duplicate, disorganized content  - especially if it's unclear who does what - like blog content competing with docs which is run by a separate team

text: I'm glad I asked, lots of great points here I need to think through.

elements.text: I'm glad I asked, lots of great points here I need to think through.

text: stresses me out just thinking about this lol!

elements.text: stresses me out just thinking about this lol!

text: I am unaware of any situation other than inheriting a mess :stuck_out_tongue:

elements.text: I am unaware of any situation other than inheriting a mess

text: haha fair

elements.text: haha fair

text: Actually, I inherited a "good SEO, low content relevance" situation where 95% of the content was top-of-funnel stuff, which may fall under the "make your own stamp" point

elements.text: Actually, I inherited a "good SEO, low content relevance" situation where 95% of the content was top-of-funnel stuff, which may fall under the "make your own stamp" point

text: Add to the list of mess: blog content is targeting transactional keywords

elements.text: Add to the list of mess: blog content is targeting transactional keywords

text: Maybe this falls under the 'inheriting a mess' bucket but joining a misaligned/demotivated/understaffed team. Sometimes the bones are there for agile strategy dev & execution (especially when the product's value is strong and clear) but the team you've joined needs coaching/a reset.

elements.text: Maybe this falls under the 'inheriting a mess' bucket but joining a misaligned/demotivated/understaffed team. Sometimes the bones are there for agile strategy dev & execution (especially when the product's value is strong and clear) but the team you've joined needs coaching/a reset.

text:
<@U01V7P0HZ51> I'll chime in with something of a mirrored situation:

Joining an enthusiastic team with tons of planning and direction, but they're decades behind on their tech stack (e.g. managing everything with email instead of a good PM solution) and have way too much process.

Cure approach: Kick 90% of the cooks out of the kitchen, streamline bloated processes, re-evaluate what actual risks are for the modern age, update tech to serve vs hinder

elements.text:
I'll chime in with something of a mirrored situation:

Joining an enthusiastic team with tons of planning and direction, but they're decades behind on their tech stack (e.g. managing everything with email instead of a good PM solution) and have way too much process.

Cure approach: Kick 90% of the cooks out of the kitchen, streamline bloated processes, re-evaluate what actual risks are for the modern age, update tech to serve vs hinder

text: The most common experience I’ve had is that there is a decent base of TOFU thought leadership content…but nothing beyond that to support the buyer’s journey (whether it’s self-serve or sales-driven).

elements.text: The most common experience I’ve had is that there is a decent base of TOFU thought leadership content…but nothing beyond that to support the buyer’s journey (whether it’s self-serve or sales-driven).

text: Before starting the agency, I commonly ran into starting from scratch when working with seed - series b startups

elements.text: Before starting the agency, I commonly ran into starting from scratch when working with seed - series b startups

text:
· you’re walking into a situation with a high volume of low-quality content
· you’re talking with a team that’s unaware of what top, middle, bottom of funnel content is

elements.text:
· you’re walking into a situation with a high volume of low-quality content
· you’re talking with a team that’s unaware of what top, middle, bottom of funnel content is

text:
You’re walking into a company that’s still figuring out their market fit and positioning.

You’re walking into a company that’s been doing founder-led marketing and the founder has a hard time releasing control.

You’re walking into a company that has years worth of content but not even a basic content calendar. 

I can go on. :wink:

elements.text: You’re walking into a company that’s still figuring out their market fit and positioning.

You’re walking into a company that’s been doing founder-led marketing and the founder has a hard time releasing control.

You’re walking into a company that has years worth of content but not even a basic content calendar. 

I can go on.

text: these are all such great answers

elements.text: these are all such great answers

text: thank you!!

elements.text: thank you!!

text: I also love what Marc Thomas is doing with content at Powered By Search. His podcast, “Inflection Point” is great, and he’s doing a helluva job doing the actual storytelling part of B2B.

elements.text: I also love what Marc Thomas is doing with content at Powered By Search. His podcast, “Inflection Point” is great, and he’s doing a helluva job doing the actual storytelling part of B2B.

text: • You're walking into a company where the leadership team understands the product extremely well and feels certain about what they want to say about it, but they don't know anything about marketing. Quite possibly, you'll have to justify everything you do; they'll short circuit processes that need time to play out, demanding ROI in 3 weeks for an effort that needs 6 months; they'll ignore what you've learned from interviews and your data because "they already know what the message should be", etc.

elements.text: You're walking into a company where the leadership team understands the product extremely well and feels certain about what they want to say about it, but they don't know anything about marketing. Quite possibly, you'll have to justify everything you do; they'll short circuit processes that need time to play out, demanding ROI in 3 weeks for an effort that needs 6 months; they'll ignore what you've learned from interviews and your data because "they already know what the message should be", etc.

text: • The contributors to date have deep industry and product expertise but don't know content marketing; they'll become a roadblock to getting stuff out the door by nitpicking details that don't matter

elements.text: The contributors to date have deep industry and product expertise but don't know content marketing; they'll become a roadblock to getting stuff out the door by nitpicking details that don't matter

text: • This one would be your fault, but it happens all the time. Your job is to create more demand with the strategy; you develop a grand plan and present it, and then find out that they've allocated about 10% of the budget they'd need to in order to make any of this work. Now you're on the hook for results but have no resources.

elements.text: This one would be your fault, but it happens all the time. Your job is to create more demand with the strategy; you develop a grand plan and present it, and then find out that they've allocated about 10% of the budget they'd need to in order to make any of this work. Now you're on the hook for results but have no resources.

text: Here's a hypothetical scenario: There's an SEO team that everyone conveniently forgot to mention during the interview process but wouldn't be a big deal if they weren't churning out poorly written, low-quality content using briefs directly from SEO tools, ignoring a massive mountain of outdated, useless decaying content, and refusing every attempt to collaborate while habitually telling you to how the same strategy you successfully executed years prior to generate compound growth towards a multibillion dollar IPO and they read about in a blog post is a better one than your current one.
